Fig. 4 . =
T. rockii Boivin (1945: 115)
. Type:— CHINA . Gansu : Upper Tebbu country (= Tewo county ), below Shimen, Tsaluku valley , in forests of spruces, willows, etc., 11000
ft., July‒August 1925 , J.F. Rock 13054 ( holotype GH00038614!). Fig. 2 .

Description :—Perennial herbs. Roots fibrous. Stem 50–120 cm tall, more or less puberulous when young, particularly so on the upper part, later usually glabrescent but sometimes still puberulous on nodes. Basal leaves 2–3-ternate, withered at anthesis. Cauline leaves 3–4-ternate; leaf blade triangular, 7–25 cm long and broad; leaflets obovate, rhombic-elliptic, ovate or suborbicular, 0.5– 3 cm long, 0.5–2.5 cm broad, herbaceous, adaxially sparsely puberulous, later often glabrescent, abaxially often puberulous, base broadly cuneate, rounded or subcordate, apex obtuse or acute, 3-lobed; lobes obtusely 2‒3-dentate, apex obtuse or acute; veins submerged adaxially, prominently raised abaxially; petioles 0.5‒ 6 cm long, with stipules at base, sparsely puberulous, later glabrescent; stipules 1‒1.5 cm long, 0.5‒ 1 cm broad, oblong, sheath-like, membranous, margin entire. Inflorescence a terminal thyrse, 10‒15 cm long; rachis sparsely or densely puberulous, later glabrescent. Pedicels 3‒10 mm long, sparsely or densely puberulous, later glabrescent. Flowers bisexual, erect. Sepals 4‒5, caducous, ellliptic, obovate or nearly oblong, 2.5– 5 mm long, 1.5‒2.2 mm broad,

adaxially glabrous, abaxially totally or distally puberulous or ciliate only on the upper margin, white or tinged with yellowish-green. Stamens 30‒50, 5‒ 8 mm long; filaments 4‒7 mm long, proximally filiform, distally thicker, white; anthers ca. 1 mm long, oblong, apex obtuse or acute, pale yellow. Carpels 4–9, more or less puberulous, stipitate; stipe ca. 1 mm long; ovary obliquely obovate, compressed; style 1.5‒1.8 mm long, straight; stigma oblong, ca. 0.5 mm long. Achenes 8‒15 mm long, more or less puberulous when young, glabrescent or sparsely puberulous when mature, stipitate, drooping; stipe 3‒7 mm long, filiform; body obliquely broadly obovate, 4‒7 mm long, 3.5‒ 5 mm broad, compressed, shallowly 2‒3-ribbed; style persistent, straight.
Phenology :—Flowering from June to August; fruiting from July to September.

Distribution and habitat :—
Thalictrum przewalskii
is widely distributed in Beijing , northeastern Chongqing , Gansu , Hebei , western Henan , western Hubei , northern Hunan , southern Nei Mongol , southern Ningxia , southeastern Qinghai , southern Shaanxi , Shanxi , northern and western Sichuan , and eastern Xizang , China ( Fig. 13 ). It grows, often together with Berberi s,
Rosa
,
Rubus
,
Salix
or
Sorbaria species
, in bushes, forests or on grassy slopes at altitudes of 750‒3500 m above sea level.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 15 . Type specimens of
Thalictrum sparsiflorum
. A. Inset: aggregate fruit. B. Inset: aggregate fruit.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Notes :—Two specimens Wang (2018) cited under
Thalictrum sparsiflorum
,
Beijing Chin. Trad. Med. Exped. 417
(PE01197733) from Mentougou district in Beijing city and Miyun Exped. 502 (PE01204172) from Xinglong county in Hebei province ( Fig. 14 ), actually belong to
T. przewalskii
.
Thalictrum sparsiflorum
is similar to
T. przewalskii
in habit and having 3‒4-ternate leaves, narrowly clavate filaments, stipitate carpels and compressed achenes, but differs by having few-flowered and leafy inflorescences, apically reflexed pedicels, and shorter stipes of carpels and of achenes ( Figs. 15 , 16 ; Maximowicz 1877, Wang & Wang 1979, Fu & Zhu 2001). It is widely distributed in northeastern Asia and North America, but in China , it occurs only in eastern Heilongjiang and eastern Jilin provinces (Anonymous 1975, Wang & Wang 1979). The two specimens just mentioned above should be referred to
T. przewalskii
, not
T. sparsiflorum
, by having many-flowered, not leafy inflorescences, erect, not apically reflexed pedicels, and long stipitate carpels and achenes ( Fig. 14 ). Our survey of
Thalictrum
specimens in the major Chinese herbaria, including CDBI, HNWP, IBSC, IFP, KUN, NAS, PE, SZ, and WUK, also indicates that in China
T. sparsiflorum
occurs only in Heilongjiang and Jilin , not in Beijing and Hebei as stated by Wang (2018).
